Pepper bell Bacterial spot.cause: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria, often spread by contaminated seeds and water.
Pepper bell Bacterial spot.symptoms: Dark, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation and reduced yield.
Pepper bell Bacterial spot.treatment: Use disease-free seeds, apply copper-based fungicides, and practice crop rotation.

Pepper bell healthy.symptoms: Leaves are vibrant green with no visible spots, curling, or discoloration.
Pepper bell healthy.treatment: Maintain good soil health and ensure proper irrigation.

Potato Early-blight.cause: Fungal infection caused by Alternaria solani.
Potato Early-blight.symptoms: Brown concentric spots on leaves, leading to yellowing and wilting.
Potato Early-blight.treatment: Use resistant varieties, remove infected plants, and apply fungicides.

Potato Late-blight.cause: Caused by Phytophthora infestans, a water mold.
Potato Late-blight.symptoms: Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, leading to rapid plant death.
Potato Late-blight.treatment: Apply fungicides, remove infected plants, and avoid overhead irrigation.

Potato healthy.symptoms: Strong plant with healthy green leaves and no spots.

Tomato Bacterial spot.cause: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria, commonly spread in warm, wet conditions.
Tomato Bacterial spot.symptoms: Small water-soaked spots on leaves and fruit, leading to leaf drop and fruit rot.
Tomato Bacterial spot.treatment: Use copper sprays, avoid overhead watering, and remove infected plants.

Tomato Early-blight.symptoms: Dark, target-like spots on older leaves, causing yellowing and defoliation.
Tomato Early-blight.treatment: Use fungicides, plant disease-resistant varieties, and rotate crops.

Tomato Late-blight.cause: Caused by Phytophthora infestans, a highly destructive pathogen.
Tomato Late-blight.symptoms: Greasy, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, often with white mold growth.
Tomato Late-blight.treatment: Apply fungicides, remove infected plants, and avoid humid conditions.

Tomato Leaf Mold.symptoms: Yellow spots on the upper side of leaves, with velvety mold underneath.
Tomato Leaf Mold.treatment: Ensure good air circulation, reduce humidity, and apply fungicides.

Tomato Septoria leaf spot.symptoms: Small, circular brown spots with gray centers on leaves, leading to leaf loss.
Tomato Septoria leaf spot.treatment: Remove infected leaves, apply copper-based fungicides, and avoid wet foliage.

Tomato Spider-mites (Two spotted spider-.cause: Caused by Tetranychus urticae mites feeding on leaves.
Tomato Spider-mites (Two spotted spider-.symptoms: Yellowing and speckled leaves, often with fine webbing.
Tomato Spider-mites (Two spotted spider-.treatment: Spray plants with water, use neem oil or insecticidal soap.

Tomato Target Spot.cause: Fungal infection caused by Corynespora cassiicola.
Tomato Target Spot.symptoms: Dark concentric rings on leaves, stems, and fruit.
Tomato Target Spot.treatment: Use fungicides, remove infected plant parts, and improve air circulation.

Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.cause: Caused by a virus transmitted by whiteflies.
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.symptoms: Upward curling leaves, yellowing, and stunted growth.
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.treatment: Control whiteflies, use virus-resistant tomato varieties.

Tomato mosaic virus.cause: A viral infection affecting tomato plants.
Tomato mosaic virus.symptoms: Mottled, distorted leaves and reduced fruit yield.
Tomato mosaic virus.treatment: Remove infected plants, avoid handling plants after touching infected ones.

Tomato healthy.symptoms: Leaves are green, strong, and free of spots or discoloration.
Tomato healthy.treatment: Maintain good soil health and watering practices.
